results.title: Watch Scenes From These Eight Best Picture Nominees
results.abstract: Inventive and surprising moments happened in front of and behind the camera this awards season. Here’s a look at memorable sequences in the top contenders.
des_facet: All Quiet on the Western Front (2022) (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Clockwise from top left: Michelle Yeoh in “Everything Everywhere All at Once,” Tom Cruise in “Top Gun: Maverick,” Austin Butler in “Elvis” and Cate Blanchett in “Tár.”

results.title: ‘Scream VI’ Review: Yes, Another Scary Movie
results.abstract: Ghostface and meta commentary are back in this sequel, yet the weight of obligations to the dictates of the franchise ultimately drags it down.

multimedia.caption: Melissa Barrera, left, and Jenna Ortega in “Scream VI.”
Melissa Barrera, left, and Jenna Ortega in “Scream VI.”
Melissa Barrera, left, and Jenna Ortega in “Scream VI.”

results.title: Could ‘All Quiet on the Western Front’ Win Best Picture?
results.abstract: Being a war movie in the Oscar race has its pros and cons.

results.title: Twenty Years Later, ‘Irreversible’ Still Shocks
results.abstract: A look back at Gaspar Noé’s brutal told-in-reverse drama, which has been rereleased in a “Straight Cut” version.

multimedia.caption: Monica Bellucci as Alex in “Irreversible: Straight Cut.” This version envisions the night of Alex’s assault in chronological order.
Monica Bellucci as Alex in “Irreversible: Straight Cut.” This version envisions the night of Alex’s assault in chronological order.
Monica Bellucci as Alex in “Irreversible: Straight Cut.” This version envisions the night of Alex’s assault in chronological order.

results.title: … It’s the Oscars that Got Small
results.abstract: On the eve of Hollywood’s big, if diminished, night, two deeply researched books dig into the scandal-soaked history of the Academy Awards.
des_facet: Oscar Wars: A History of Hollywood in Gold, Sweat, and Tears (Book)
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

multimedia.caption: Gloria Swanson at a New York nightclub, awaiting by radio link the results of the 1951 Academy Award for best actress. At left is Judy Holliday, who bested Swanson for the prize.
Gloria Swanson at a New York nightclub, awaiting by radio link the results of the 1951 Academy Award for best actress. At left is Judy Holliday, who bested Swanson for the prize.
Gloria Swanson at a New York nightclub, awaiting by radio link the results of the 1951 Academy Award for best actress. At left is Judy Holliday, who bested Swanson for the prize.

results.title: Inside the ‘Blood Sport’ of Oscars Campaigns
results.abstract: War rooms. Oppo dumps. Eight-figure budgets. How the quest for awards-season glory got so cutthroat.
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

results.title: ‘Therapy Dogs’ Review: It’s Time to Be Real
results.abstract: This low-budget film by a pair of high schoolers offers a bracing, impressionistic portrait of senior year as it’s happening.

multimedia.caption: Justin Morrice in “Therapy Dogs,” directed by Ethan Eng, who wrote and stars in the film with Morrice.
Justin Morrice in “Therapy Dogs,” directed by Ethan Eng, who wrote and stars in the film with Morrice.
Justin Morrice in “Therapy Dogs,” directed by Ethan Eng, who wrote and stars in the film with Morrice.

results.title: How Michael B. Jordan and Jonathan Majors Fought Harmoniously
results.abstract: One’s a big name, and one’s about to be. But to get along on ‘Creed III,’ they had to let go of ego and trust each other to pull no punches.

multimedia.caption: Michael B. Jordan, right, said he worked to persuade Jonathan Majors to sign on. The co-star had his concerns: “There was nothing historically that said an actor was going to look after another Black actor.”
multimedia.copyright: Gioncarlo Valentine for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Michael B. Jordan, right, said he worked to persuade Jonathan Majors to sign on. The co-star had his concerns: “There was nothing historically that said an actor was going to look after another Black actor.”
multimedia.copyright: Gioncarlo Valentine for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Michael B. Jordan, right, said he worked to persuade Jonathan Majors to sign on. The co-star had his concerns: “There was nothing historically that said an actor was going to look after another Black actor.”

results.title: Watch Cate Blanchett Break Down in ‘Tár’
results.abstract: The writer and director Todd Field narrates an emotional moment from his film, which stars Cate Blanchett and is nominated for six Oscars.

multimedia.caption: Cate Blanchett in “Tár.”
Cate Blanchett in “Tár.”
Cate Blanchett in “Tár.”

results.title: ‘Unicorn Wars’ Review: Teddy Bears in Battle
results.abstract: The contrast between this animated film’s grim subject matter and its bubbly animation style is a big part of what makes it so creepy, our critic writes.

multimedia.caption: “Unicorn Wars” follows two sibling bears, Bluey and Tubby, as they train for battle in the forest and ingest hallucination-inducing worms.
“Unicorn Wars” follows two sibling bears, Bluey and Tubby, as they train for battle in the forest and ingest hallucination-inducing worms.
“Unicorn Wars” follows two sibling bears, Bluey and Tubby, as they train for battle in the forest and ingest hallucination-inducing worms.

results.title: ‘Rewind & Play’ Review: Thelonious Monk Dazzles Even When an Interview Falls Flat
results.abstract: Alain Gomis’s documentary uses rushes from a 1969 French TV interview to make a smart indictment of music industry bias and offer viewers a subtle tribute to Monk.

multimedia.caption: Thelonious Monk in “Rewind & Play.”
Thelonious Monk in “Rewind & Play.”
Thelonious Monk in “Rewind & Play.”

results.title: ‘The Magic Flute’ Review: Mozart Meets C.G.I., With Help From a Tween
results.abstract: A young tenor enters a world enlivened by computer graphics at a school devoted to the composer’s works in this Roland Emmerich-inspired film.

multimedia.caption: Jack Wolfe in “The Magic Flute.”
Jack Wolfe in “The Magic Flute.”
Jack Wolfe in “The Magic Flute.”

results.title: ‘Luther: The Fallen Sun’ Review: Psycho Filler
results.abstract: A smoldering Idris Elba is no match for the preposterousness of this feature-length Netflix continuation of the popular BBC crime thriller.

multimedia.caption: Idris Elba in “Luther: The Fallen Sun.”
Idris Elba in “Luther: The Fallen Sun.”
Idris Elba in “Luther: The Fallen Sun.”

results.title: ‘Champions’ Review: Following the Playbook
results.abstract: This film directed by Bobby Farrelly has elements that recall “Kingpin” and “There’s Something About Mary.” But the ratio of tastelessness to sentimentality has been reversed.

multimedia.caption: From left, Casey Metcalfe, James Day Keith, Woody Harrelson, Ashton Gunning and Tom Sinclair in “Champions.”
From left, Casey Metcalfe, James Day Keith, Woody Harrelson, Ashton Gunning and Tom Sinclair in “Champions.”
From left, Casey Metcalfe, James Day Keith, Woody Harrelson, Ashton Gunning and Tom Sinclair in “Champions.”

results.title: Cautionary Climate Tales That Give People Pause When They Press Play
results.abstract: The India-born director Joshua Ashish Dawson builds digital worlds that ruminate on the future shock of environmental destruction in the real world.

multimedia.caption: In his short film “Denervation,” Joshua Ashish Dawson, who explores “speculative climate futures” that concern global health and the environment, imagined threats posed by counterfeiting in an unscrupulous pharmaceutical industry.

In his short film “Denervation,” Joshua Ashish Dawson, who explores “speculative climate futures” that concern global health and the environment, imagined threats posed by counterfeiting in an unscrupulous pharmaceutical industry.

results.title: With Its Future at Stake, the Academy Tries to Fix the Oscars (Again)
results.abstract: The awards telecast has been losing viewers for years. New leadership wants to reverse that starting Sunday, and ensure the financial well-being of the organization.
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

multimedia.caption: Janet Yang, the president of the academy, and Bill Kramer, its chief executive, want to make the Oscars feel more approachable to more viewers.
multimedia.copyright: Philip Cheung for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Janet Yang, the president of the academy, and Bill Kramer, its chief executive, want to make the Oscars feel more approachable to more viewers.

results.title: Lukas Gage on the Audition That Went Awry, ‘You’ and Writing His Own Ticket
results.abstract: Three years after his apartment was shamed by a director during a video tryout, the “You” actor is taking on his first lead role — in a film he co-wrote.

multimedia.caption: When a filmmaker, not realizing the Zoom mic was on, belittled his apartment, Lukas Gage said, “I remember having this weird feeling in the pit of my stomach afterward, like, why am I judging where I’m at in my 20s, at the beginning of my career?”
multimedia.copyright: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: When a filmmaker, not realizing the Zoom mic was on, belittled his apartment, Lukas Gage said, “I remember having this weird feeling in the pit of my stomach afterward, like, why am I judging where I’m at in my 20s, at the beginning of my career?”
multimedia.copyright: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: When a filmmaker, not realizing the Zoom mic was on, belittled his apartment, Lukas Gage said, “I remember having this weird feeling in the pit of my stomach afterward, like, why am I judging where I’m at in my 20s, at the beginning of my career?”
multimedia.copyright: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times

results.title: Topol, Star of ‘Fiddler on the Roof’ on the Screen and the Stage, Dies at 87
results.abstract: Wide acclaim for the role of Tevye helped make him, according to one newspaper, “Israel’s most famous export since the Jaffa orange.”

multimedia.caption: Chaim Topol, generally known simply as Topol, in 1966. He won fame for playing Tevye in “Fiddler on the Roof,” a role he performed more than 3,500 times on stage over the decades, as well as appearing in the film version in 1971.
multimedia.copyright: Evening Standard/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images

multimedia.caption: Chaim Topol, generally known simply as Topol, in 1966. He won fame for playing Tevye in “Fiddler on the Roof,” a role he performed more than 3,500 times on stage over the decades, as well as appearing in the film version in 1971.
multimedia.copyright: Evening Standard/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images

multimedia.caption: Chaim Topol, generally known simply as Topol, in 1966. He won fame for playing Tevye in “Fiddler on the Roof,” a role he performed more than 3,500 times on stage over the decades, as well as appearing in the film version in 1971.
multimedia.copyright: Evening Standard/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images

results.title: Bert I. Gordon, Auteur of Mutant Monster Movies, Dies at 100
results.abstract: Despite low budgets and years of mostly negative reviews, he gained a cult following for his giant villains, homemade effects and preposterous plotlines.

multimedia.caption: From left, Basil Rathbone, Estelle Winwood and Bert I. Gordon on the set of “The Magic Sword” (1962), one of the first of the roughly 25 films Mr. Gordon produced, directed and often wrote.
From left, Basil Rathbone, Estelle Winwood and Bert I. Gordon on the set of “The Magic Sword” (1962), one of the first of the roughly 25 films Mr. Gordon produced, directed and often wrote.
From left, Basil Rathbone, Estelle Winwood and Bert I. Gordon on the set of “The Magic Sword” (1962), one of the first of the roughly 25 films Mr. Gordon produced, directed and often wrote.

results.title: ‘The Outsiders’ Review: Growing Pains Both Brutal and Poetic
results.abstract: At La Jolla Playhouse, the musical adaptation of the novel and film has considerable appeal, but is weighed down by too many characters and themes.

multimedia.caption: “The Outsiders,” set amid an environment of vacant lots and broken-down cars, maps the increasingly bloody conflict between the Greasers and the Socs.
“The Outsiders,” set amid an environment of vacant lots and broken-down cars, maps the increasingly bloody conflict between the Greasers and the Socs.
“The Outsiders,” set amid an environment of vacant lots and broken-down cars, maps the increasingly bloody conflict between the Greasers and the Socs.

results.title: A24, the Indie Film Studio, Buys New York’s Cherry Lane Theater
results.abstract: The studio’s first venture into live performance follows the move by Audible, Amazon’s audio subsidiary, to stage works at the nearby Minetta Lane Theater.

multimedia.caption: The Cherry Lane Theater in Manhattan’s West Village has been bought by A24, the independent film and television studio.

results.title: ‘Everything Everywhere’ Wins Writers Guild Award, Sweeping Major Guilds
results.abstract: The victory for Daniel Scheinert and Daniel Kwan cements the film’s front-runner status. Sarah Polley’s “Women Talking” takes the adaptation prize.

multimedia.caption: Daniel Scheinert, left, and Daniel Kwan with their trophies for original screenplay for “Everything Everywhere All at Once.”
Daniel Scheinert, left, and Daniel Kwan with their trophies for original screenplay for “Everything Everywhere All at Once.”
Daniel Scheinert, left, and Daniel Kwan with their trophies for original screenplay for “Everything Everywhere All at Once.”

results.title: Review: Chris Rock’s ‘Selective Outrage’ Strikes Back
results.abstract: A year after Will Smith slapped him at the Oscars, Rock responded fiercely in a new stand-up special, Netflix’s first experiment in live entertainment.

multimedia.caption: Chris Rock’s new Netflix stand-up special, “Selective Outrage,” was packaged more like a major sporting event, a star-studded warm-up act to the Oscars next week.
Chris Rock’s new Netflix stand-up special, “Selective Outrage,” was packaged more like a major sporting event, a star-studded warm-up act to the Oscars next week.
Chris Rock’s new Netflix stand-up special, “Selective Outrage,” was packaged more like a major sporting event, a star-studded warm-up act to the Oscars next week.

results.title: Ricou Browning, Who Made the Black Lagoon Scary, Dies at 93
results.abstract: He helped bring “Flipper” to the movies and TV but was best known for his plunge in a monster suit in “Creature From the Black Lagoon.”

multimedia.caption: Ricou Browning in costume as the Gill Man, also known as the Creature From the Black Lagoon, in 1953.
Ricou Browning in costume as the Gill Man, also known as the Creature From the Black Lagoon, in 1953.
Ricou Browning in costume as the Gill Man, also known as the Creature From the Black Lagoon, in 1953.

results.title: ‘¿Será que me merezco tanto?’: Ricardo Darín y los Oscar
results.abstract: El actor ha protagonizado las cuatro películas por las que su país ha sido nominado este siglo, pero él cree que más que su talento, su mayor suerte es la confianza que otros han tenido en él.

multimedia.caption: Ricardo Darín, actor en activo desde que era un niño, dice: “¿Será que me merezco tanto?”.

results.title: Heads Up: A Better Movie Seat May Cost You
results.abstract: As the film business changes rapidly, multiplexes are experimenting with prices in ways that may seem shocking to theatergoers.

multimedia.caption: AMC Entertainment is trying a program that bases prices for seats at evening shows on their location in relation to the screen.
multimedia.copyright: Philip Cheung for The New York Times

results.title: Tom Sizemore, Intense Actor With a Troubled Life, Dies at 61
results.abstract: He earned praise for his work in films like “Saving Private Ryan” and “Black Hawk Down.” He also served prison time for drug possession and domestic abuse.

multimedia.caption: Tom Sizemore, left, with Tom Hanks in “Saving Private Ryan” (1998). Mr. Sizemore and eight other actors from that film were nominated for a Screen Actors Guild Award for outstanding cast.
Tom Sizemore, left, with Tom Hanks in “Saving Private Ryan” (1998). Mr. Sizemore and eight other actors from that film were nominated for a Screen Actors Guild Award for outstanding cast.
Tom Sizemore, left, with Tom Hanks in “Saving Private Ryan” (1998). Mr. Sizemore and eight other actors from that film were nominated for a Screen Actors Guild Award for outstanding cast.

results.title: ‘The Holly’ Review: The Tragic Case of a Denver Activist
results.abstract: Julian Rubinstein’s investigative documentary traces the engrossing case of a Denver community organizer, Terrance Roberts, who faced charges of attempted murder
des_facet: The Holly: Five Bullets, One Gun, and the Struggle to Save an American Neighborhood (Book)

multimedia.caption: Terrance Roberts in the documentary “The Holly.”
Terrance Roberts in the documentary “The Holly.”

results.title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks are all thrillers, with scares coming from a single-family cult, a monster drug deal and other weirdness.

results.title: For Sale: Memories From One of Hollywood’s Most Enduring Love Stories
results.abstract: More than 300 items that belonged to Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward will be sold in June in a series of auctions run by Sotheby’s in New York.

multimedia.caption: Joanne Woodward with her husband, Paul Newman, and the Oscar that she won in 1958 for her role in “The Three Faces of Eve.”
Joanne Woodward with her husband, Paul Newman, and the Oscar that she won in 1958 for her role in “The Three Faces of Eve.”

results.title: ‘Palm Trees and Power Lines’ Review: A Teen’s Cautionary Tale
results.abstract: Lily McInerny stars as a 17-year-old girl who is groomed by a predator in Jamie Dack’s feature debut.
